Award.AwardTitle: A Workshop US-Brazil on Cyber Security and Privacy

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this workshop is to bring together American and Brazilian cyber security researchers to discuss the main challenges of the field, and to promote cross-collaboration and the building of ties among the attendees. The workshop will be organized in two meetings, one in Brazil in the fall of 2015, and one in the US in the spring of 2016. The attendees will be comprised of about 35 American and Brazilian researchers in cyber security and privacy in universities in the US and in Brazil.

This workshop promotes innovation in solving cyber security and privacy problems, by having the top researchers from both countries, from several sub-fields sharing their research and brainstorming solutions for open problems in the area. Having a scientific discussion on cyber security and privacy with Brazilian academics can increase the visibility and applicability of American technology in other countries, and increase the diversity of students applying to undergraduate and graduate programs in the US. Brazil is a large a diverse democracy with significant scientific strengths, and this proposal helps improve connections between the two countries. Additionally, this workshop will strengthen the US-Brazil Bilateral Cooperation on Education, which includes the Brazil Scientific Mobility program, which has funded almost 30,000 Brazilian students at various levels in American educational institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this pair of workshops was to bring together, for the first time, American and Brazilian cyber security researchers from academia, industry, and government to discuss the main challenges of the field and to promote cross-collaboration and the building of ties among the attendees. The workshops also had the aim of (i) promoting innovation in solving cyber security and privacy problems by having the attendees sharing their research and brainstorming solutions for open problems in the area; (ii) helping researchers share their experiences in education, student recruitment, career development, and entrepreneurship, and to get involved, together with their students and trainees, in international projects, and (iii) identifying areas of overlap among American and Brazilian research works to foster future collaborations. 

The workshop was organized in two meetings, one in Brazil and one in the US, and involved American and Brazilian cyber security researchers and practitioners. The first meeting happened on December 3-4, 2015, at the University of Brasilia in Brasilia, Brazil. The second meeting happened in Orlando, Florida (Hyatt Regency) on April 7-8, 2016. During the workshops participants presented their research and experience, discussed timely topics on several panels and worked on small breakout sessions on the most pressing problems in cyber security at the time (Web Security Across All Devices, Human Factors in Cyber Security and Privacy, Science of Security, Security for Lightweight IoT Devices, Cybercrime, Malware, and Intrusion Detection, and Federated Command and Control for Cyber Operations) and the opportunities and challenges for collaborations between the two countries. Participants also attended 5-minute scheduled meetings randomly pairing attendees from each country. Among the workshop attendees were the Brazilian Secretary for Science, Technology, and Innovation (MCTI), Celso Pansera; the Assistant Director for the Directorate for Computer & Information Sciences & Engineering for the National Science Foundation (NSF), Jim Kurose; and the Cyber Security Division Director for the Department of Homeland Security, Doug Maughan. 

Two reports were generated with the results of the breakout sessions for the Brasilia and the Orlando workshops. At the end of the Orlando workshop an MOU was signed between the countries for a joint grant solicitation, which culminated with a Dear Colleague Letter (DCL) solicitation between the NSF and the Brazilian MCTI (https://www.nsf.gov/pubs/2017/nsf17024/nsf17024.jsp?WT.mc_ev=click), which attracted more than 60 submissions of collaborative proposals of more than 200 US and 100 Brazilian-based researchers. The initiative awarded five grants receiving $300K from each country funding agency, totalling $600K per award.

After the workshop, many researchers established new collaborations and developed new research ideas based on this new knowledge and networking opportunity.  As examples of new collaborations, Fabian Monrose (University of North Carolina), Diego Aranha (UNICAMP, Brazil) and Anderson Nascimento (University of Washington Tacoma). Daniela Oliveira (University of Florida), Andre Gregio (Federal University of Parana, Brazil), and Paulo Licio de Geus (UNICAMP, Brazil) continued their collaboration with visits among their institutions in the US and Brazil involving their PhD students, resulting in three published papers.

More information about the workshop, including agenda, participant information, reports, and pictures can be found at: http://www.usbrazilsec.org/
